That's an excellent point. We are so US-centric, we forget that movies are a very international business. Films are NOT made just for US consumption alone, but must make a lot of their money back from foreign sales and distribution, including DVD sales and now, downloads.

What would "fly" for US consumers, would be a dud for many foreign audiences -- among other things, loud action films are easily understood by foreign audiences. Sensitive, introspective, touchy-feely films -- not so much.

In many of these cultures, they would not identify with a tough female protagonist and that would doom overseas profits. In some cultures, the very idea of a female in power would be offensive or inscrutable.

The studios know their market very precisely, and it is for loud, male-oriented action films, which are the biggest money-makers.
Possibly so. But from the historical record, those countries seem a lot more comfortable than ours with a female in THE lead: head of state.

Keep in mind that Hollywood now makes its big-budget action movies as much for overseas audiences as for North Americans. Overseas revenue can make up half or more of a big release's earnings, and possibly more with some action franchises.

While Europeans (at least some of them) might be open to female action heroes, it's far from certain that Middle Easterners, Africans, Asians and/or Latin Americans would. And with the huge amounts of money the studios spend on big action films, it's hardly surprising that they'd be risk-averse.

Neoclassical economists just keep running in circles over this downward wage rigidity. This is a prime indicator of the intellectual bankruptcy of their theory and how divorced it is from capitalist reality.

It never occurs to neoclassicals that the real wage is necessary for the maintenance and reproduction of the laborer and his/her family in a normal state of health and vitality. Marx analyzed this as the value of labor power. This is why it doesn't fall in recessions in the face of massive unemployment. If it decreased as neoclassicals theorize (labor supplied greater than labor demanded), the real wage would fall below the working class's subsistence level. For a time, decreases in real wages for one worker can be compensated by the spouse working or going into debt. That is, the real wage isn't determined by supply and demand curves. It is determined by the morally and historically determined value of the means of subsistence for the working class. This regulates the value of labor power and its form of appearance as the wages of labor.

No bitcoin wallet has ever been hacked. The thefts are all a result of scam companies or upstart companies that don't secure their servers, the same way credit card numbers are often stolen. People who don't know what they're doing, which is natural with a new technology that lacks refined software and a mature user base, often choose to store their wallets with shady companies, so is it any wonder that these companies steal or end up losing their BTC?

The easiest way to understand why people are speculating so wildly on BTC right now is to look at its unique qualities:

1) It's so far unhackable. As I wrote above, no one has ever stolen a bitcoin without stealing its private key. It would be like if someone invented a safe that could not be broken into without the combination and had a combination so complex that all the computers in the world, all networked together, couldn't guess it in a million years. That alone has some value.

2) It's uncontrollable. If you have a private key to a wallet, you can send btc to any other address.

3) It's universally accessible. Because no one controls bitcoin, no one can say who is or isn't allowed to hold create a BTC address and receive or send BTC.

4) It's pseudonymous and can be anonymous without much work.

5) It's near free to move it to anyone in the world in a matter of minutes.

Simply put, there is nothing else that can do what bitcoin does, and what bitcoin does is extremely valuable. It's the system that gives it value.

I spoke to some very clever scientists who are studying the oil-from-algae process.

Some problems with it. You need enormous amounts of surface area for the sunlight to furnish the necessary energy for the reaction. Bank after bank of transparent tubes with the algae and nutrients flowing through them, presented towards the sun.

Scale-up problems will, consequently, be daunting.

When I asked these scientists for samples of their process, for evaluation as refinery feedstock or motor fuel, they replied plaintively, "Will 100 milliliters be enough?"

In other words this technology is not ready for prime time.

When I asked how much the process would cost, on a commercial scale, the scientists started waving their arms and talking fast and shrill.

The answers ranged from $16 per gallon to "around" $60 per gallon.

Per gallon.

Try not to get too excited about this one, folks.

Excellent points. I am an avid "estate-saler" and go to all types of tag sales, yard sales, garage sales year-round.

I have a very good idea of what sells, in all types of situations, and I can tell you (and more importantly, Mr. Friedman) that USED CLOTHING is not some big growth industry that nobody else has tapped into.

The reason is that clothing depreciates faster than even cars. That $20 kids outfit your child outgrew before they even wore it? It's now worth 50 cents.

It's great for people to re-use items, but the reason they do it, is to save money -- like that grandma with the drug-addled daughter. If she had to pay you $10 an outfit, she would have bought one (or none) -- not a bagful.

Mr. Friedman's "business model" (another naive one he has bought into, like HireArt or AirBnB) simply does not work in the real world.....unless your vision of America is like some open air market in Somalia, with people selling rags by the roadside for pennies.
Goodwill can't even sell clothes. They throw lots of clothes out.
Try Salvation Army, Goodwill Industries is a rip-off whose CEO lives like a king while employing people for slave wages.

Last summer, I cleaned out the closets and rented a table at a group sale in a nice space. I was counting on the higher-ticket items to make enough profit to replace my worn-out walking shoes. I had a mix of vintage collectibles, books, toys, and clothes from all stages of my teen daughter's life. I was advised by the organizers that clothes didn't sell well, but these were clean items in good to excellent condition that the resale shops wouldn't take because they were too far past season. If they didn't sell, their next stop was Goodwill.

The little girls' clothes such as tops and shorts I was virtually giving away at 25 cents each. I sold every piece. One grandmother bought three sacks full for her three granddaughters. With tears in her eyes, she told me that their irresponsible, drug-addled mother barely cared for them, and the girls had few clothes. She was so happy to get a nice wardrobe for them for a few dollars. Another woman bought the similarly priced children's books, most like new, for the waiting room at a food bank she worked at, because the kids whose parents were there to get food didn't have books at home and loved having the chance to sit and read for fun. I threw in a few free.

I didn't meet my goal, and I'm still trying to save up money for those shoes. I did learn some important economic lessons, though not how to get rich selling stuff.
